ticket.title: Patch that adds an exception
ticket.original-body: @@@ ruby <%= link_to 'bla', '#', {:onclick => "document.merge_form.submit()", :confirm => "Really?"}%> @@@ will result in @@@ html bla @@@ with my onclick just eaten without any notice. If this isn't done for a specific reason I would propose 2 possible solutions. Allow only one of the two being set and throw an exception Wrap the onclick JS in the confirm I totally understand that I will have to write the patch myself and just wanted to check if this is not for some reason intended behaviour, if it is I could add a comment on this to the link_to method.
ticket.latest-body: @@@ ruby <%= link_to 'bla', '#', {:onclick => "document.merge_form.submit()", :confirm => "Really?"}%> @@@ will result in @@@ html bla @@@ with my onclick just eaten without any notice. If this isn't done for a specific reason I would propose 2 possible solutions. Allow only one of the two being set and throw an exception Wrap the onclick JS in the confirm I totally understand that I will have to write the patch myself and just wanted to check if this is not for some reason intended behaviour, if it is I could add a comment on this to the link_to method.
ticket.original-body-html:
<%= link_to 'bla', '#', {:onclick => "document.merge_form.submit()", :confirm => "Really?"}%>

will result in


<a onclick="return confirm('Really?');" href="#">bla</a>

with my onclick just eaten without any notice. If this isn't done for a specific reason I would propose 2 possible solutions. Allow only one of the two being set and throw an exception Wrap the onclick JS in the confirm

I totally understand that I will have to write the patch myself and just wanted to check if this is not for some reason intended behaviour, if it is I could add a comment on this to the link_to method.

If this isn't done for a specific reason I would propose 2 possible solutions. Allow only one of the two being set and throw an exception Wrap the onclick JS in the confirm I totally understand that I will have to write the patch myself and just wanted to check if this is not for some reason intended behaviour, if it is I could add a comment on this to the link_to method.

<%= link_to 'bla', '#', {:onclick => "document.merge_form.submit()", :confirm => "Really?"}%>

will result in


<a onclick="return confirm('Really?');" href="#">bla</a>

with my onclick just eaten without any notice. If this isn't done for a specific reason I would propose 2 possible solutions. Allow only one of the two being set and throw an exception Wrap the onclick JS in the confirm

I totally understand that I will have to write the patch myself and just wanted to check if this is not for some reason intended behaviour, if it is I could add a comment on this to the link_to method.
version.title: :confirm overwrites :onclick

version.body:
I can't speak to what the intention is here, but if you look at the documentation for the link_to_function method, you'll one example of what you're trying to do
@@@ ruby link_to_function(image_tag("delete"), "if (confirm('Really?')) do_delete()") @@@
http://api.rubyonrails.org/classes/ActionView/Helpers/JavaScriptHelper.html#M001724
Maybe raising an exception or a warning would be a good idea, but I'm not sure that wrapping the onclick in the confirm is obvious.
version.body-html:
I can't speak to what the intention is here, but if you look at the documentation for the link_to_function method, you'll one example of what you're trying to do


  link_to_function(image_tag("delete"), "if (confirm('Really?')) do_delete()")

http://api.rubyonrails.org/class...

Maybe raising an exception or a warning would be a good idea, but I'm not sure that wrapping the onclick in the confirm is obvious.
version.title: :confirm overwrites :onclick

version.body: I hope this is acceptable, it does pretty much what the other exception does
version.body-html: I hope this is acceptable, it does pretty much what the other exception does
version.title: Patch that adds an exception

version.body: Please add tests to this patch.
version.title: Patch that adds an exception

version.body: In Rails master seems to do just what it should. Rails 3 utilizes the HTML5 attribute data-confirm to handle the confirmation. @@@ rails <%= link_to 'bla', '#', {:onclick => "document.merge_form.submit()", :confirm => "Really?"}%> @@@ Outputs: @@@ html bla @@@ Since it seems unnecessary, my vote: -1
version.body-html:
In Rails master seems to do just what it should. Rails 3 utilizes the HTML5 attribute data-confirm to handle the confirmation.

<%= link_to 'bla', '#', {:onclick => "document.merge_form.submit()", :confirm => "Really?"}%>

Outputs:

<a href="#" data-confirm="Really?" onclick="document.merge_form.submit()">bla</a>

Since it seems unnecessary, my vote:

-1
version.title: Patch that adds an exception
